8.44.text:
As a kid I used to
dream about the oceans.

10.94.text:
It was this wild place
full of color and life.

14.98.text: Home to these alien-looking fantastical creatures.

18.99.text: I pictured massive sharks ruling the food chain

22.22.text: and graceful sea turtles dancing across coral reefs.

25.99.text:
As a marine biologist
turned photographer,

27.99.text:
I've spent most of my
career looking for places

31.23.text: as magical as those I used to dream about when I was little.

35.80.text: I wish to share with you all this evening.

39.17.text: So, one of the most common

40.84.text: questions I receive from people is,

43.51.text: "What is the most terrifying moment of your career?"

47.01.text: Now, being in my shoes at this moment

49.02.text: must be really, really, really scary.

51.72.text: And, you know, I'll be honest, I am scared.

58.02.text:
I'm scared of getting
the sharks out of focus

60.29.text:
and I'm scared that
my editors are

61.83.text:
not going to like a single
picture that I'm taking.

66.40.text:
they are probably the least
of my concern right now.

68.63.text: And, you know, remember these are pretty small sharks

72.17.text:
So, if sharks are not the
scariest part of my job,

77.18.text:
There's one creature
that if it congregates

79.18.text:
in large enough numbers, it
scares the crap out of me.

82.88.text:
And this is what these
creatures look like.

86.99.text: The scariest moments of my photographic career

90.26.text: are without a camera, on a stage

92.16.text: looking over an ocean of people.

93.83.text: You know, give me a white shark

95.19.text: or a Sharknado any day of the week.

99.37.text:
But I'm getting ahead of myself
here, way ahead of myself.

101.90.text:
And like with any good story,
I think we have to begin

107.74.text: Now I began exploring bodies of water at a fairly young age.

112.08.text: They were a lot smaller than the ones I explore now

114.18.text: but at that stage, I thought, you know

115.88.text: they were probably as exciting as

117.32.text: the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean are for me today.

121.95.text: Today my photography is largely anchored in conservation.

125.79.text: And, you know, with conservation photography

128.56.text:
I call it "the carrot and
the stick" approach.

130.80.text: On the one hand, you can showcase them

132.40.text: the most amazing places on this planet and make them go, "Wow!"

135.97.text: I could not believe a place like

139.27.text: And hopefully they make a connection with it.

141.97.text: I have this incredible privilege to document

143.88.text: some of the most amazing marine realms on our planet.

149.41.text: I need to document the reality

151.75.text:
of our relationship
with the oceans.

153.39.text:
So, for the other half of
the year, I document, what I

156.36.text: sort of call the darker side

157.82.text: of our relationship with the sea.

160.56.text: the impacts of climate change or oil-spills.

162.66.text:
But I always feel like I
walk a very fine line

168.10.text:
When young photographers
always ask me,

170.07.text:
"What is, sort of, number
one tip you can give me?"

173.81.text:
I always say, "Begin
in your backyard."

176.84.text:
Begin with a subject
and a place that

180.95.text:
and a place that you can go back
to again and again and again.

185.02.text:
In South Africa, I had a
pretty sexy backyard.

190.96.text:
And my first, sort of, real
reportage story was about

195.66.text: You know, 12 years ago, I mean, when I shot this

198.00.text: this was the, sort of, standard white shark image.

200.20.text: You know, focus on the teeth, aggressive, dangerous, wild and

203.47.text: these sort of pictures are easy to take.

205.67.text:
However, the more time I
spent out at sea with them

209.81.text:
the less I felt that that
picture was accurate.

212.34.text:
Instead of the aggressive, you
know, dangerous white shark,

215.62.text: I was seeing an inquisitive, and very often, curious creature.

220.25.text:
The image that follows
is the one picture

222.15.text:
that I think best represents
the white shark to me.

225.56.text: And this was taken on one of those wonderful winter days

228.19.text: the water was clear, the sea was calm and you know

230.70.text: this white shark came across this little box-jellyfish.

232.97.text: And, I thought it would either

234.63.text: swim through it or just ignore it

236.20.text: and for a few seconds this white shark actually almost hovered.

239.81.text: As if it was transfixed by the light on the tentacle

242.41.text: and it just kinda, you know, hovered there

243.94.text: and just looked, as if going

247.61.text:
And, you know, after she had
satisfied her curiosity

250.38.text:
that's a three and half
year female by the way

252.15.text:
she just kind of, you
know, turned back

254.15.text: and went back into the depths.

255.79.text:
And that is, sort of,
how I know great whites,

262.23.text: My next reportage was also in Southern Africa again.

265.40.text: But the focus here is on sardines.

268.40.text: Now, sardines are a cold water fish

270.34.text: and they prefer the west and south coast

273.67.text: However, once a year something unusual happens.

276.21.text:
We have this warm current
on the east coast

279.61.text:
And, once a year it
kind of moves offshore.

282.05.text: And these sardines migrate with this cold water northwards.

285.69.text: And we call this the "sardine run".

287.22.text: And, you know, sardines, heavily over-fished over the years

289.99.text: and this is a species that

290.99.text: really needs the conservation attention but

293.56.text: everyone thinks it lives in tin cans.

296.43.text:
It's not just the fishing fleets
that follow these sardines.

298.70.text: There's a whole suite of predators

303.94.text: smaller pieces of sardines off the massive shoals

307.11.text: and they pin and herd them up to the surface.

309.71.text: And, you know, there they form

311.74.text: the holy grail for all photographers.

315.98.text: I've done the run for eight years. I've seen three.

319.15.text: So, the dolphins herd the sardines

321.65.text: and they take turns, you know, one after the other

324.02.text: they'll rush in grab a sardine and swim out

334.07.text: these sharks have a really hard time.

335.77.text: They get sardine donuts, as we call them.

338.47.text: Mouths full of water most of the time.

341.97.text: the sardines tend to be herded together much more closely.

344.48.text: Working with sharks on the run

345.98.text: is a little bit spicy at times.

348.38.text: Especially, at the end when there's very few sardines left

351.78.text: they treat you like another shark.

353.89.text: So, you get bumped and hit probably every ten-seconds.

357.29.text:
And if you want to
get good pictures

358.89.text:
you just have to ignore the
sharks knocking into you.

360.93.text: Most of the time I know I'm not on the menu.

362.93.text: These sharks feed on small sardines.

365.50.text:
one, I had a large dusky
shark rip-off my fin

368.63.text:
and swim away with it.
What's that all about?

371.10.text:
Why does that shark
need another fin, I...

375.54.text:
And then another one, I had
two bronze whaler sharks

379.01.text:
each hanging on to my
underwater strobes

380.95.text:
and I felt like a
Ukrainian weight-lifter.

382.75.text:
-( audience laughter )
-I was trying to punch...

384.82.text:
They obviously like,
when the strobe recycles

387.22.text:
there seems to be an
electro-current that kind of

388.95.text:
you know, gets
pushed out, so they

390.52.text:
they love biting
on those things.

393.43.text: This is my favorite sardine run photograph.

395.66.text: For two reasons. One, it was in clear water

397.66.text: and you know, it looks like the shark is inhaling the sardines.

400.87.text: And right after this, he basically

402.57.text: swings around and comes at me.

403.97.text: You can see these little sardine heads and tails sticking out

408.81.text: That's what that reminded me of, it's just one of those

411.34.text: you know, interesting visual scenes there.

413.45.text: But, yeah, you know, that's one of those images

414.95.text: you know, once every eight years, if you're lucky.

417.65.text: At the end of the, you know, bait ball

419.62.text: when there's few sardines left, where do they wanna go?

421.92.text: In between your legs, under your arms, around your head.

424.79.text: The sardines are seeking shelter around you.

427.79.text: Which is a really, really bad place to be

429.93.text: not just because of the sharks.

431.00.text: And there's actually a bigger danger on the run.

433.00.text:
I'm photographing and I'm
looking at screen at something

435.20.text:
and as I look up, all
the predators are gone.

438.70.text: You know, it's just me and the sardines

439.94.text: and we're looking at each other going,

442.37.text: You know, they're too stunned to actually swim away

444.04.text: 'cause they don't know what's going on.

446.41.text: Instinct kicks in and I go, "I'm going where they've gone."

449.01.text:
I am back-paddling, I'm swimming
out of the bait ball and...

452.15.text: this guy comes rocketing out of nowhere.

454.42.text: -( audience gasping ) -It's a Bryde's whale, and...

457.66.text: He comes up and he pretty much

458.96.text: in front of me, swallows the entire bait ball.

463.43.text: I'm probably a foot or two away

464.80.text:
and as he does that
he arches upwards

467.20.text:
and then he pretty much
just leaves the water.

469.04.text: I mean, they have all this energy

470.94.text: and he leaps out of the water

472.14.text:
two-thirds come up and
I am, more or less

475.81.text:
right at the left where the
sardine is leaping out.

482.95.text: So, I curl into this little ball

484.18.text:
and I'm waiting for the sound
of hearing my own bones break.

490.76.text:
And the next picture I
have no recollection.

492.83.text:
I have no memory,
but I have this.

496.33.text: So, this is all the water streaming

498.03.text: out of the Bryde's whale's mouth.

501.40.text: Somebody else could have taken this.

502.60.text: It was in my camera at the end of the day.

505.00.text: It's very hard to see, you know, in stills.

507.64.text: So this is sort of, some video of a colleague of mine.

510.18.text: You get the idea of the whole...

512.11.text: how quick and how crazy that bait ball actually is.

517.78.text: Imagine trying to get still pictures in that.

520.95.text: And you have to be where those sharks are.

522.76.text: You have to be one of those sharks, to get the pictures.

526.96.text: So, it gets a bit crazy at times but...

530.60.text: And this is where the birds are just, you know

541.21.text: And here comes the Bryde's whale.

548.91.text:
So, now you get
an idea, sort of,

551.92.text: And you sort of just have to...

556.72.text:
forget about all that stuff and
